awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Long-Range, Millimeter-Wave, Wireless Power Beaming with Enhanced Efficiency
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to drive high-tech industry development in the Midwest region of the United States. This team develops and deploys wireless, power-beaming technologies for applications in both civilian and military contexts. The project explores wireless generation and distribution of mass energies through electromagnetic waves. The resulting technology spans applications from the wireless charging of vehicles to green energy distribution and solar power beaming. Immediate applications include long-distance flights of heavy-duty drones, which can be remotely charged from terrestrial power beaming stations. With the addition of relay drones, this technology may also establish a resilient airborne energy distribution network for military purposes. In the long term, the technology's scalability enables solar power beaming, a significant leap toward carbon-free green energy production.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the fundamental limitations of existing wireless power-beaming technologies. Conventional methods suffer from poor efficiency and require large physical dimensions for Radio Frequency transmitters and receivers. These limitations have made a long-range power-beaming solution impractical. To overcome these obstacles, this project aims to develop a unique operational mode for wireless power-beaming technology: power beaming at the near-field zone using millimeter waves. This approach offers significant advantages, including improved efficiency, compact dimensions, outstanding long-range performance, and safe operation. By leveraging the extended near-field range of a transmitter operating at millimeter waves and utilizing an adaptively controllable collimated beam, the technology can significantly enhance power efficiency, allowing power to be transmitted over much greater distances. Furthermore, a uniquely devised frequency plan within the low-loss region of atmospheric transmission windows enhances the system's resilience in adverse weather conditions. The utilization of shorter wavelengths in the millimeter-wave spectrum enables substantial reductions in the size of transmitting and receiving systems. Precise control of the transmitter's focal point ensures a secure and reliable power-beaming connection between subsystems. This technology has the potential to revolutionize wireless power beaming, facilitating efficient transfer of high powers and unlocking capabilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Maxwave has successfully completed its Phase I NSF project, achieving significant breakthroughs in wireless power beaming technology. This innovative project addressed longstanding challenges that have historically impeded the commercialization of wireless power systems. By overcoming these barriers, Maxwave is now well-positioned to scale the technology, paving a clear path toward transformative market opportunities. Beyond the technological advancements, this project underscores Maxwave commitment to its broader mission: building a sustainable business rooted in cutting-edge innovation. Operating in an underrepresented region, Maxwave contributes to the socioeconomic development of the community, fostering job creation and advancing novel science and technology that ultimately enhance societal well-being and strengthen the United States' global competitiveness.

Intellectual Merit - Existing wireless power transfer methods suffer from poor efficiency, also limiting their operational range and practical applications. While increasing the physical dimensions of transmitters and receivers can slightly improve efficiency, this approach is impractical for many use cases. In response to these challenges, Maxwave has developed an innovative wireless power-beaming technology that leverages a unique operational mode and the advantages of millimeter-wave frequencies. By utilizing a collimated beam and electrically larger apertures at millimeter-wave frequencies, the technology offsets the slightly increased atmospheric losses at these frequencies. This approach enhances system efficiency over extended distances, delivering superior performance compared to conventional methods. Maxwave patent-pending transmitter is meticulously designed to minimize loss components in the system. This innovative design focuses power precisely on the receiver, ensuring maximum efficiency and effectiveness in energy delivery. Additionally, the shorter wavelengths inherent to the millimeter-wave regime enable a significant reduction in the size of the transmitting and receiving components. Maxwave technology also incorporates precise control of the transmitter’s focal point, ensuring a secure and reliable power-beaming connection between subsystems. This capability not only enhances operational safety but also allows for efficient energy delivery over vast distances. With its ability to transfer large amounts of power efficiently, Maxwave innovation has the potential to revolutionize wireless power-beaming, unlocking new possibilities for high-performance energy delivery in diverse applications.

Broader Impacts - The impacts of Maxwave project extend well beyond its scientific and intellectual contributions, delivering long-lasting benefits and a transformative societal impact. Collaborations with top-tier universities and international partners have significantly strengthened Maxwave innovation pipeline and technology transfer efforts. These partnerships have established a robust foundation for sustainable economic growth, especially in the technology-hungry Midwest region of the United States. By fostering cutting-edge advancements in wireless power beaming, Maxwave contributes to the region's economic vitality while addressing critical technological gaps. Maxwave commitment to environmental sustainability is evident in its efforts to reduce reliance on traditional energy resources and infrastructure while advancing renewable energy solutions. By addressing critical challenges in wireless power beaming, Maxwave has opened new frontiers in both civilian and military applications. These include enabling energy delivery to remote regions, supporting disaster response, advancing airborne energy distribution networks in tactical scenarios, and facilitating smart agricultural practices through wireless-enabled drones. Through these contributions, Maxwave is shaping a future of technological and environmental progress while enhancing societal well-being and the global competitiveness of the United States.

 


Last Modified: 12/10/2024
Modified by: Mirhamed Mirmozafari
